bugs.title: CVE-2020-26570 opensc: heap-based buffer overflow in sc_oberthur_read_file

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2020-26570 opensc: heap-based buffer overflow in sc_oberthur_read_file

long_desc.thetext:
The Oberthur smart card software driver in OpenSC before 0.21.0-rc1 has a heap-based buffer overflow in sc_oberthur_read_file.

References:
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=24316
https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/commit/6903aebfddc466d966c7b865fae34572bf3ed23e

Created opensc tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1885949]
Affects: fedora-all [bug 1885948]

Flaw summary:
sc_oberthur_read_file() in src/libopensc/pkcs15-oberthur.c attempts to read an invalid record from the card reader APDU interface by reading a record greater than file->record_count, causing an out-of-bounds write.

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2021:1600 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2021:1600

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2020-26570

bugs.title: CVE-2020-26571 opensc: stack-based buffer overflow in sc_pkcs15emu_gemsafeGPK_init

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2020-26571 opensc: stack-based buffer overflow in sc_pkcs15emu_gemsafeGPK_init

long_desc.thetext:
The gemsafe GPK smart card software driver in OpenSC before 0.21.0-rc1 has a stack-based buffer overflow in sc_pkcs15emu_gemsafeGPK_init.

References:

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=20612

Created opensc tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1885951]
Affects: fedora-all [bug 1885952]

Flaw summary:
In  `sc_pkcs15emu_gemsafeGPK_init()` routine in src/libopensc/pkcs15-gemsafeGPK.c, kinfo was defined as `keyinfo kinfo[8];` but an off-by-one error in loop `for (i = 7; i < 16; i++)` could access up to `kinfo[9]`, causing a stack buffer overflow and passing this to sc_read_record(), potentially causing an out-of-bounds write. The patch declares `keyinfo kinfo[9]` instead.

Upstream patch: https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/commit/ed55fcd2996930bf58b9bb57e9ba7b1f3a753c43

AFAIK, the fix for this issue is the following commit:

https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/commit/ed55fcd2996930bf58b9bb57e9ba7b1f3a753c43

As mentioned in the issue, I was not able to reproduce the issue with the given vectors (and I am not able to reproduce it now either), but the following issue looks very similar:

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=22319

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2021:1600 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2021:1600

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2020-26571

bugs.title: CVE-2020-26572 opensc: stack-based buffer overflow in tcos_decipher

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2020-26572 opensc: stack-based buffer overflow in tcos_decipher

long_desc.thetext:
The TCOS smart card software driver in OpenSC before 0.21.0-rc1 has a stack-based buffer overflow in tcos_decipher.

References:

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/oss-fuzz/issues/detail?id=22967
https://github.com/OpenSC/OpenSC/commit/9d294de90d1cc66956389856e60b6944b27b4817

Created opensc tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: epel-6 [bug 1885955]
Affects: fedora-all [bug 1885956]

Flaw summary:

In  the tcos_decipher() routine of src/libopensc/card-tcos.c, a call to `memcpy()` of size `crgram_len` could overflow past the end of the `sbuf` buffer, causing an out-of-bounds write. This could occur when `crgram_len` is greater than the size of `SC_MAX_APDU_BUFFER_SIZE`. The patch ensures that if `crgram_len` is greater than `sbuf - 1`, an error is returned instead.

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2021:1600 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2021:1600

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2020-26572
